definition: The abstract concept of a user trigger that initiates a process or side-effect (e.g., 'Save', 'Delete'). It decouples the trigger (Button) from the handler.
A positioning reference point that allows an element to place itself relative to another element (the anchor), handling collision and flipping.
usage: Standardized by Anchor Intent (CSS Anchor Positioning).

definition: A reusable functionality pattern attached to a component via composition rather than inheritance.
The UX state where user interaction is prevented to ensure data integrity during a critical process.
A modular, visual UI component that follows strict interoperability standards.
Viewport width thresholds that trigger layout changes. In Web Everything, these are tokenized to ensure consistency across JS and CSS.
A raw HTML file representing a specific usage scenario. Serves as the Single Source of Truth for documentation examples and E2E test fixtures.
An encapsulated custom element with its own shadow DOM and lifestyle.
A UI component managing focus for its children (e.g., Listbox, Grid) via specific keyboard patterns like Roving Tabindex.
A mechanism for hierarchical data flow and service provision across component trees, independent of the DOM structure.
A design pattern where a component's dependencies are provided to it, rather than created by it. Enables loose coupling and easy testing.
Structural markers (loops, conditionals) and comment logic that manipulate the DOM structure.
The handling of text direction (LTR vs RTL) and its impact on layout, icons, and interaction logic.
The simulated Z-axis depth of an element, typically conveyed via shadows or layering, indicating hierarchy.
The strategy for forcing content into a container (Cover, Contain, Fill) preserving aspect ratio.
usage: Used across Media and Layout blocks.

definition: The orchestration of keyboard navigation and active element state. Includes trapping, restoring, and cycling focus.
Error tolerance level where the operation failed but the application state remains valid.
usage: A core principle of Reliability Intent.

definition: Visual symbols standards including sizing scales, stroke weights, and positioning strategies to ensure optical balance.
Standardization of data entry interfaces, including affordances, privacy masking, virtual keyboard types, and validation feedback.
The handling of input modalities (pointer, touch, gamepad, keyboard) and the feedback loops required for each.
A system for registering and handling key combinations that works with Shadow DOM and standard OS conventions.
The organization of protocols from abstract intents down to concrete implementation details.
The application shell structure and region mechanics (Drawers, Rails, Panels) that define the macro-layout.
The standardized state machine (Idle -> Loading -> Success/Error) that drives the UI. It separates the 'Process' (Time) from the 'Outcome' (Data).
usage: Resource Loaders and Actions must expose their lifecycle capabilities.

definition: The visualization of pending operations, defining how the UI reacts (Blocking, Skeleton, Spinner) to latency.
The system for prioritizing and displaying communication to the user, from subtle toasts to blocking alerts.
A dialog or overlay that forces user interaction before returning to the main content. Defines stacking, scrolling, and dismissal behavior.
A self-contained unit of functionality or UI that expects a specific host context.
The physics, latency tolerance, and transition behaviors that define the 'feel' of the application.
The structure of application flow (Hierarchical, Lateral, Linear) and the mechanism for transitioning between views.
Code that implements a feature on web browsers that do not support the feature.
Declarative strategies for placing elements relative to the viewport or other elements.
usage: Standardized by Layout and Anchor logic.

definition: The strategy of loading resources before they are required, balanced against bandwidth and battery constraints.
A system for defining and looking up capabilities or components via a global or scoped lookup mechanism.
Strategies for error recovery, retry policies, and maintaining a viable state during failure conditions.
A behavioral directive that attaches asynchronous mutation lifecycle management to UI triggers.
A structural pattern used to handle asynchronous data fetching and state display in-place.
A focus management pattern where `tabindex="0"` moves to the currently active item, while others are set to `-1`.
The behavior of choosing items from a set, defining cardinality (Single vs Multi) and required state.
Standard primitives for observability, data binding, and reaction to data changes (Signals, Stores).
The definition of visual depth (Z-Axis), material qualities (Opaque, Transparent), and their interactive properties.
The unified handling of temporal selection and display across different input modalities (Calendar, Dial, Text).
A parsed unit of meaning within a text node or attribute, often used for data binding.
A record of an execution path through the application. Composed of multiple 'Spans' (units of work).
An engine responsible for recording execution flow (Traces) and context. It can be injected into any scope.
A categorization tag for traces (e.g., 'Network', 'Render', 'UserInteraction') allowing different tracers to subscribe to specific domains.
A granular, composable capability mixed into a component class (e.g., `withSortable`).
The abstraction of visual text hierarchy (Headline, Body, Caption) from semantic HTML elements.
The lifecycle of data integrity checking, error message placement, and submission blocking.
An element implementation using markers (e.g., comments) to avoid introducing redundant container nodes in the DOM.
usage: Used elsewhere to preserve CSS Grid/Flex relationships.

definition: See 'Case'.
